Issues.Title: Reduced nesting levels by inverting a few top-level `if`s
Issues.Body:
In #9540 I was asked to rebase my changes on `Net9.0-Test`, so I closed that pull request and opened this one.

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

## Proposed changes

The logic of certain `if` blocks has been inverted. Namely:
- Some setters and some methods have `if` blocks that span more than a screen full of text, which makes it hard to see where the block ends. By inverting the logic, the `if` block becomes an `if` guard that is just one more element in the sequence of instructions.
- Also, some `if` blocks in certain setters could be better described and understood as guards, which is not very clear if the block spans all or at least most of the body of the setter. 

## Customer Impact

- No direct customer impact. The code is functionally identical

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Low. Only safe, localized refactorings have been applied, aided by Visual Studio

Issues.Title: MdiContainer Form throw error when multipul call Dispose() method.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-rc.1.23369.12

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes
This issue only be occured on .net8

### Issue description

In a video below:

- Set the form's IsMdiContainer property to True.
- Add a new form, and set it's MdiParent to form.
- Show the two forms.
- Call form's Dispose() two times.
![MdiDisposeTwice](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/46096500/e39e2e80-3267-4390-9f1b-2005703818a2)

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/46096500/2a2974c1-31a6-446b-920a-3adf56c0e796)


### Steps to reproduce

Build and run 
[MdiDisposeTwice.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/12116091/MdiDisposeTwice.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "MdiContainer Form throw error when multipul call Dispose() method." (#9534)

Issues.Title: SetWindowsHookEx API is not working for mouse actions in .NET7.0
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.net .7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes , it is working in .net6.0 and earlier versions

### Issue description

The mouse action is not captured by the SetWindowsHookEx API in .Net7.0 which works in the earlier version.

I have already created an issue regarding this but the solution given in that was not worked for me.
link-https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/8965

### Steps to reproduce

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11198683/WinFormsApp1.zip

Run the attached sample

- Perform the mouse action(mouse move, mousedown, Mouse up)

- The Writeline operation in the method MouseHookProc will not be performed

Note- These will be working in .NET6.0 and earlier version
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SetWindowsHookEx API is not working for mouse actions in .NET7.0" (#9535)

Issues.Title: An exception popped up when click "Print with error" button
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

 .NET 8.0.100-rc.1.23369.12

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

In a video below:
- "Print successfully" button sets PrintPreviewControl.Document property to a document of 1 page;
- "Print with error" button sets PrintPreviewControl.Document property to a document that fails to generate a preview;
- "Reset" button sets PrintPreviewControl.Document property to null.

Note that an exception pops up a few seconds after clicking "Print with error" button

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/108860782/28cd18ab-dac4-40e0-a5b9-a004dea2bb13

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/108860782/30de529b-a432-42d9-8b2e-c157bf311e9f)
**Call Stack:**
System.Exception
  HResult=0x80131500
  Message=Something went wrong.
  Source=SampleApp
  StackTrace:
   at SampleApp.Form1.ErroneousDocument.OnPrintPage(PrintPageEventArgs e) in C:\Users\v-mandiman\Desktop\SampleApp\SampleApp\Form1.cs:line 73
   at System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.PrintLoop(PrintDocument document)
   at System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.Print(PrintDocument document)
   at System.Windows.Forms.PrintPreviewControl.ComputePreview()
   at System.Windows.Forms.PrintPreviewControl.CalculatePageInfo()


### Steps to reproduce

- Build and run [SampleApp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/12115642/SampleApp.zip)
- Click "Print with error" button and observe it
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "An exception popped up when click "Print with error" button" (#9533)

Issues.Title: Cleanup for utilization of target new
Issues.Body:
Tweaks the editor config settings to encourage behavior that matches our coding style:

- We prefer `Foo foo = new()` over `var foo =`.
- `var` for built in types is an error
- Expression bodied members are always ok

A number of the rules got added by just using the editor. I'll continue to iterate.

Changed a big chunk of the code to use target typed new using fixers and regex's for the majority of the changes.
